title: Graphql: Sorting the reports by jira_status field resulted to different value

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
Sorting the reports by jira_status yield to different result depicting the team is using jira even the user has no access.
**Description:**
A user with no access to jira information of any reports can somehow access the jira field using order_by through `jira_status`
Using the 2 graphql below we can see the discrepancies of `total_count` for the test teams i will mention:

__Test Teams:__
1.  █████████
order_by:field:`id` = `total_count: 10`
 order_by field:`jira_status`= `total_count :11`
2.  ██████████ : 
order_by:field:`id` = `total_count: 458`
 order_by field:`jira_status`= `total_count :466`
3.  ████
order_by:field:`id` = `total_count: 299`
 order_by field:`jira_status`= `total_count :309`
4. ███
order_by:field:`id` = `total_count: 109`
order_by field:`jira_status`= `total_count :110`


Graphql Query using field `id` in`order_by` as criteria it will yield same result except for the field of `jira_status`
```
{
  reports(where: {team: {handle: {_eq: "██████"}}}, order_by: {direction: ASC, field: id}) {
    total_count
    nodes {
      substate
      jira_escalation_state
      jira_escalation_last_state_change_at
      created_at
      disclosed_at
      extracted_report_data {
        hosts
      }
      title
      url
      team {
        handle
      }
      reporter {
        username
      }
    }
  }
}
 ```
Please change the field in `sort_by` to` jira_status` to display different result.

Below is part of the response using jira_status as the field, please notice that `jira_escalation_state`and `jira_escalation_last_state_change_at` has null values meaning a ==public user don;t have access to this information.==
{
  "data": {
    "reports": {
    =="total_count": 11, ==
      "nodes": [
        {
          "substate": "resolved",
          "jira_escalation_state": null,
          "jira_escalation_last_state_change_at": null,
          "created_at": "2019-09-18T11:57:36.488Z",
          "disclosed_at": "2020-04-21T02:53:04.699Z",
          "extracted_report_data": null,
          "title": "███",
          "url": "███",
          "team": {
            "handle": "████████"
          },
          "reporter": {
            "username": "█████"
          }
        },

Additional information: I dig more on the discrepancies and checked the returned reports 1 by 1 to  and compare result, in Team ███████, the report ███████ appeared twice because of the sort_by jira_status.


Thank you.
Ariel

## Impact

Due to improper access control in the `sort_by` of `jira_status` field any user can give an idea which report are using jira even if the user has no access jira information.

activities.message:
Only `jira_status` is yielding different result, if a user tried other field like `create_at` (publicly available information) it will result to normal  but if a user don't have access to the field like  `latest_activity_at` it will return error message `can only filter on latest_activity_at as a team member` 

` reports(where: {team: {handle: {_eq: "██████"}}}, order_by: {direction: ASC, field: latest_activity_at})`
 = error message `can only filter on latest_activity_at as a team member`


`reports(where: {team: {handle: {_eq: "█████"}}}, order_by: {direction: ASC, field: created_at})`
=no error message, returned `total_count` =109
same result if we change  field to `timer_report_resolved_elapsed_time` , `triaged_at` , `last_reporter_activity_at` `timer_bounty_awarded_elapsed_time`

BUT 
` reports(where: {team: {handle: {_eq: "███"}}}, order_by: {direction: ASC, field: jira_status})`
=no error message, returned `total_count` =110

Hi @0619 - thanks for your report! I'm not entirely sure if this is a security vulnerability, so I've escalated it to the team that maintains our integrations for them to figure out why you're seeing the count discrepancy when ordering by the field. We'll keep you posted. Thanks!
Perhaps, the team will figure out what's going on!
Hello Sir, have you  heard anything from the integration team? thank you.amj
Hi @0619 - the team has started to look at it, I expect to have an update next week. Thanks for your patience!
Thank you Sir, if you don't mind i would like to take a look at any graphql mutation bug/issue  related to a report with a status of triage just like mine now.

Hi @0619 - the team confirmed that this vulnerability can be used to determine which report has a JIRA status set based on the order, like you described in your report. The team didn't find a way to determine the contents of the status field. This wasn't the same as the other report you mentioned. In this case, the team had used a JOIN statement without the proper authorization in place. Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, nice find!
Thank you for the bounty. i wish i can get a swag :)

@jobert  Hello Sir, forgive me if I'm still exploring my report while it's still in Triage status. I just want to explore all the possibilities.
Like this one, i was able to invite my other account (test account 2584) to join as collaborator. 
Based on the UI, you need to specify a percentage of bounty the collaborator will receive when you send an invite, since I already received my bounty, don't know what will happen in the back-end of H1 for the added collaborator.

Is it correct to prevent the reporter to add collaborators once he received the bounty?

By the way, i tested again `jira_status`  and I confirm the fix works, i don't see any discrepancies in total_count.

Respectfully,
0619

Hi @0619 - like you noticed, we pushed a fix for this issue - thanks again for reporting it and retesting it!

> Is it correct to prevent the reporter to add collaborators once he received the bounty?

No, it is expected that you can add a collaborator afterwards. A program can award any number of bounties on a report, so collaborators can come and go as needed. It doesn't retroactively update bounties, so adding a collaborator afterwards doesn't affect anything.

I didn't get a retesting pay? :)  
Thank you very much for the bounty.

Hi @0619 - ha, that felt a bit odd to go through the retest flow after you had already retested it, but I guess I can work around it like this, too. Let's wait with a retest next time so we can capture the proper data. Thanks!
OK Sir, sorry, thank you again, more power to H1.
